title: Observing How the Universe Changed over Time

previous.title: The Cosmic Microwave Background and the Growth of Galaxies

content:
The distribution and concentration of matter in the Universe for sizes larger than a galaxy is called the large-scale structure of the Universe. Astronomers can use the location of the distance to billions of galaxies using data from Rubin Observatory to create a map that reveals this large-scale structure.

Here is a series of maps that show the galaxies detected by Rubin Observatory at certain distances away from Earth (expressed as redshift numbers). Lower redshift numbers correspond with distances that are closer to Earth, and higher redshift numbers correspond with distances that are farther. Each map can be thought of as a slice in time from the history of the Universeâ€”at greater distances we see the Universe as it was at earlier times. The axes of the maps (RA and Dec) show the position of these galaxies as viewed from Earth.

Select the redshift that corresponds with the earliest time, and then move through the maps to see how the Universe has changed over time.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Look at the map of the farthest distance. Does this map represent a time long ago (early in the Universe) or a recent time (later in the history of the Universe)?

question.title: Question #2
question.label: Look at the map of the closest distance. Does this map represent a time long ago (early in the Universe) or a recent time (later in the history of the Universe)?

question.title: Question #3
question.label: Describe how the distribution of galaxies in the Universe has changed over time. When were large numbers of galaxies clumped together (more concentrated) in larger groupings in some places? When were galaxies distributed more evenly in smaller groupings?
